text: Acleris cervinana is a species of moth of the family Tortricidae. It is found in North America, where it has been recorded from Alabama, Alberta, Arkansas, British Columbia, California, Illinois, Indiana, Kentucky, Maine, Maryland, Michigan, Mississippi, New Brunswick, New Hampshire, New York, North Carolina, Ohio, Ontario, Pennsylvania, Quebec, Saskatchewan, Tennessee, Vermont and West Virginia.mothphotographersgroup The wingspan is 15–17 mm. The forewings are usually deep orange-brown, with a dark brown costal triangle enclosing a white rectangular spot on the costa. In form americana, the ground colour is paler and more fawn-coloured. Furthermore, the white spot in the costal triangle is replaced by one of the ground colour.McDunnough, J. 1934. The Canadian species of the Tortricid genus Peronea. Canadian Journal of Research, 1934, 11(3): 290–332 Adults have been recorded on wing nearly year round. The larvae feed on Betula alleghaniensis, Corylus and Alnus species.Tortricidae Food Plant Database ==References== Category:Moths described in 1882 cervinana Category:Moths of North America
title: Acleris cervinana
